image.altText: An unidentifiable child rests their hand on their leg. Only their leg and hand are in focus.

items.synopsis: Desperate families have been unable to get appointments for their trans kids at this public hospital as resignations and a broader fight over gender care take a toll.

title.children: Services for new patients grind to a halt as hospital's gender clinic is pulled into fight over medical interventions for kids

image.altText: A woman and man with blonde hair sit next to a floral arrangement

items.synopsis: Older people downsizing to smaller homes is one way housing stock can be used more efficiently but despite government moves to make it more attractive financially, barriers still exist.

title.children: Downsizing could be part of the solution to the housing crisis. So why aren't more people doing it?

image.altText: A woman in a floral shirt sits at a restaurant table.

items.synopsis: Scientists are still working to unpack the mystery of why some people keep catching the virus while others seem to be resistant. In the meantime, people like Marion have been left with more questions than answers.

title.children: After 10 positive COVID tests, Marion's staging her own lockdown

image.altText: Pat Cummins pulls a face of frustration while standing next to Ben Stokes

items.synopsis: The Ashes were within reach for Australia for a fleeting moment on day four at Headingley, but it missed its most critical moment and allowed England to keep this outrageous series alive.

title.children: How Australia missed the moment that could have wrapped up the Ashes early

image.altText: Chris Woakes holds his arms in the air and yells in delight

items.synopsis: England wins the third Test by three wickets, chasing down 251 runs for victory to keep the Ashes series alive. Follow live.

title.children: England keeps Ashes alive, winning third Test with thrilling run chase at Headingley

image.altText: England batter Ben Stokes shouts after getting out in the second innings of the Ashes Test at Headingley.

items.synopsis: Ben Stokes failed to repeat his Headingley heroics, but Harry Brook and a couple of returning guns filled his shoes as England prevent Australia from winning the Ashes with two games left. Here are five things you missed overnight.

title.children: Five quick hits — Ben Stokes finally falls short, but England uncovers a few new heroes

image.altText: Man smiling while holding two glass awards in front of a red banner

items.synopsis: After convincing BHP to trial his high-tech air conditioners, Steven Heaton promised some of Australia's biggest businessmen huge returns if they invested in his company. Now he's behind bars.

title.children: He pretended to sell air conditioners to BHP and conned some of the biggest names in Australian business. Now he's behind bars

image.altText: A composite image of Xi Jinping, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, Vladimir Putin and Donald Trump

items.synopsis: Nobody can predict with certainty the outcome to the Russia-Ukraine war, but we can look at all the various pressures at play and then use those to try to assess the most likely direction from here, writes John Lyons.

title.children: Why China is the key to avoiding Ukraine's worst nightmare

image.altText: two female students carrying handbags walk through a university campus. they are facing away from the camera

items.synopsis: End Rape on Campus says fewer than a third of Australia's 39 universities are clearly reporting sexual violence on campus. The university failures are leaving students to fall into a 'black hole'.

title.children: Open letter calls for government to address 'university failures' over sexual violence

image.altText: A small brown animal behind some grass

items.synopsis: How the pademelon often tricks the world into thinking it is the extinct thylacine, and seven other wild pademelon facts.

title.children: Preyed upon and often mistaken for another species — meet the pademelon

image.altText: Two RAAF F/A-18A Hornets in close formation during Exercise Pitch Black over northern Australia in August 2014.

items.synopsis: Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has been invited to join crucial talks in Lithuania, after $110 million in military and humanitarian support for Ukraine.

title.children: Europe would be 'cheering' on Australian fighter jets sent to Ukraine, according to NATO host

image.altText: a young woman smiling and leaning her head on her hand while on a boat out on the water

items.synopsis: Chelsea Hall shared her experience with chronic bloating online. What she wasn't expecting was to see herself advertising pills that claim to fix it — pills she says she's never taken, promoted by a company she's never been a customer of.

title.children: 'They've never even sent me a message': Chelsea's videos appeared in an ad for a product she's never used

image.altText: Hands take Australian money notes out of a wallet.

items.synopsis: About 14 million Australians will be prepping their tax returns over the coming weeks and months.

title.children: Many Australians are going to notice a drop in their tax returns compared to last year. Here's why

image.altText: Photo of sandstone building with canon at front. Tree in left corner with concrete in it.

items.synopsis: Rotting and riddled with wasps, in the 1980s an ailing blue gum at Anglesea Barracks was filled with concrete to stabilise it. Almost four decades on the old tree still stands, is still alive, and the concrete is barely visible.

title.children: Rotting away from the inside out, this blue gum was filled with concrete. Four decades later it's stronger than ever

image.altText: Elizabethan-styled women's clothing in a studio

items.synopsis: After a successful career in business management Stephanie returns to her "heart work", making couture. Her passion for fashion made from paper is now being noticed in the art world.

title.children: Look closely at this couture, you won't believe what it's made of

image.altText: A man sells artwork at a stall

items.synopsis: Hobart is known for its cafe culture — and there's a new kid on the block, looking to offer something slightly different.

title.children: New cafe helping migrants and mixing business with pleasure

image.altText: A drawing of a person in a wheel-chair who is unable to cross a valley, while an abled person climbs across.

items.synopsis: Lisa is one of thousands of British police officers looking to move to Australia, but because her daughter has Down syndrome her visa application is likely to be rejected — a feature of the Migration Act.

title.children: Australia's migration law labelled discriminatory, but entirely legal, because of this major caveat

image.altText: Sign out the front of a country pub which states that Indgienous people will be refused takeaway alcohol service

items.synopsis: The Mataranka Hotel stopped serving takeaway alcohol to Indigenous people during a "community-led", short-term ban following the death of a woman in the nearby Jilkminggan community.

title.children: NT pub refuses to sell Indigenous people takeaway alcohol in short-term, 'community-led' ban

image.altText: A blurred photo of the share trading boards at the Australian stock exchange

items.synopsis: The local share market is expected to make gains at the open. US jobs numbers were below forecasts but wages growth was stronger. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX set to rise, mixed messages on US jobs market

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! Stephanie Chalmers here to take you through today's trade, which will kick off in around an hour's time. First, let's take a look back at how we ended the week. It was actually the worst weekly performance by the ASX 200 so far this year and left us at around a 3-month low. And after we'd wrapped things up for the week, US markets ended lower on their Friday, with things unravelling into the close — the Dow lost 0.6 per cent. It followed some mixed signal on the US labour market — the closely watched non-farm payrolls report was actually weaker than expected. 209,000 jobs were added in June, the smallest rise in 2.5 years, and below expectations of a 225,000 gain. And the numbers for April and May were revised down by 110,000. However, average hourly earnings were stronger than had been forecast, and as a result, bets are still on for further rate increases in the US. Markets are pricing in around a 90 per cent chance of a rate hike when the Federal Reserve meets in late July. "Payrolls was weaker than expected, though not 'weak' — with stronger-than-expected wage growth an offset in terms of how the Federal Reserve will perceive the overall data," write ANZ analysts Brian Martin and Daniel Hynes. "While there are clear cracks appearing in the labour market, the US labour force participation rate has seen a slow grind higher." Stick with us to see how it all plays out on our market.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX tipped to rise after down week

children.content: Good morning!
Stephanie Chalmers
here to take you through today's trade, which will kick off in around an hour's time.
First, let's take a look back at how we ended the week.
It was actually
the worst weekly performance by the ASX 200 so far this year
and left us at around a 3-month low.
And after we'd wrapped things up for the week,
US markets ended lower
on their Friday, with things unravelling into the close — the Dow lost 0.6 per cent.
It followed some mixed signal on the US labour market — the closely watched
non-farm payrolls
report was actually
weaker than expected
209,000 jobs were added in June,
the smallest rise in 2.5 years
and below expectations of a 225,000 gain.
And the numbers for April and May were revised down by 110,000.
However, average hourly earnings were stronger than had been forecast, and as a result, bets are still on for further rate increases in the US.
Markets are pricing in around a 90 per cent chance of a rate hike when the Federal Reserve meets in late July.
"Payrolls was weaker than expected, though not 'weak' — with stronger-than-expected wage growth an offset in terms of how the Federal Reserve will perceive the overall data," write ANZ analysts
Brian Martin
and
Daniel Hynes
"While there are clear cracks appearing in the labour market, the US labour force participation rate has seen a slow grind higher."
Stick with us to see how it all plays out on our market.

image.altText: The hand of woman wearing a grey long sleeve top rests on her patterned skirt

items.synopsis: Mary-Lou says her son used to park his car in the driveway to block her in her home before demanding money. Now the trialled program that helped her escape elder abuse is ending.

title.children: Mary-Lou says elder abuse by her son left her 'humiliated, horrified and alone'

image.altText: Nakkiah Lui wearing a brown blazer dress, not smiling, looking at camera

items.synopsis: When you think of a farmer, what image comes to mind? Nakkiah Lui asks that question on her latest podcast First Eat. If you envisioned a white man in an Akubra, you're not alone. Here's why that's an issue and the impact on your dinner plate.

title.children: Nourishment and sustenance. How you can stop being at war with food

image.altText: Compost in a bin

items.synopsis: About 7.6 million tonnes of unnecessary food waste is thrown in the bin by Australians every year.

title.children: Food waste is costing Australian households up to $3,000 a year

image.altText: A woman with a crutch and guide dog stands outside a suburban street.

items.synopsis: Victorian woman Kathryn Beaton says repeated, illegal denials of service from drivers refusing to allow her guide dog into their vehicles have left her effectively housebound.

title.children: Legally blind woman left anxious and in tears after rideshare drivers refuse to pick her up 23 times in six weeks

image.altText: A closely framed picture of several wooden boats sitting in a harbour

items.synopsis: The families of those on board have not heard from them since the three boats left Senegal on the dangerous migration route about two weeks ago.

title.children: At least 300 migrants missing at sea near Spain's Canary Islands, aid group says

image.altText: Oscar Piastri stands on a stage, with his back to a massive crowd, smiling in his Orange outfit

items.synopsis: The Australian driver was "very happy" with fourth place behind Max Verstappen at Silverstone, while Hollywood A-lister Brad Pitt made an appearance on the track.

title.children: Oscar Piastri achieves career-best in British F1 Grand Prix

image.altText: A middle-aged man in a hat and high-vis stands in a waterway, holding up strands of an invasive weed.

items.synopsis: A weevil smaller than a grain of rice has been released into waterways infested with cabomba weed, a South American plant that has been wreaking havoc in several states and territories.

title.children: Ancient enemy unleashed against one of Australia's worst aquatic weeds

image.altText: A young woman with dark brown hair streaked with turquoise smiles softly.

items.synopsis: A rise in the number of young people without a regular GP has health experts concerned it could leave them at higher risk of developing chronic health conditions later in life.

title.children: Zali was quoted up to $1,200 for a consult. Experts say young people are ditching GPs and specialists over cost

image.altText: A woman outside of her house

items.synopsis: While this 46-year-old cleaner lives in a government-subsidised house in the NSW country town of Mudgee, others in Karina's home town are simply leaving amid a worsening rental crisis.

title.children: Karina's rent in her country town doubled in six years, sinking her deep into debt

image.altText: Jane Bari in the garden

items.synopsis: A hearty garden and empty freezer have helped Jane Bari and her husband go from having just $100 to their names to a life free of debt, and something that could help other older Australians out of poverty.

title.children: How one couple changed their lifestyle to live below their means

image.altText: Signage is seen at BBC Broadcasting House offices.

items.synopsis: The broadcaster says it became aware of a complaint in May, but new allegations of a different nature were made last week.

title.children: BBC suspends presenter over claims he paid a teenager for explicit photos

image.altText: Zelenskyy and another man holding lanterns and looking sorrowful with priests in the background

items.synopsis: The Ukrainian president and his Polish counterpart remember the anniversary of the Volhynia massacre in which tens of thousands of Poles were killed.

title.children: Zelenskyy pays tribute to victims of WWII massacre of Poles by Ukrainian nationalists

image.altText: a man walks through water at a lake with a bucket

items.synopsis: Worried residents gathered at Lake Eppalock in central Victoria are calling for the state government to release more water, fearing more flooding if there is significant rain.

title.children: Lake Eppalock set to spill as anxious residents call for more help

image.altText: Centrelink sign.

items.synopsis: The Robodebt scandal didn't occur in a cultural vacuum. It was the end-point of decades of certain unemployment policies, writes Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: Robodebt was a scandal. Should economists bear some responsibility for it too?

image.altText: time lapse image of satellites orbiting over a astronomy station

items.synopsis: Scientists, looking deep into space, have long voiced their concerns that satellites are encroaching on their ability to study the cosmos.

title.children: Scientists prove Elon Musk's Starlink satellites are interfering with ability to study the cosmos

image.altText: A white woman wearing a purple jacket standing in front of the Coburn Hotel.

items.synopsis: Slim Dusty once played there and it was bustling pre-pandemic, but now the doors are shut at Cockburn's pub with locals fearing the tiny town will die without its business.

title.children: Plenty of beer but no-one to run 130yo pub as town fights to 'keep place alive'
